results.title: Rainbow serpent
results.creator_credit: Richard Guthrie, Commonwealth Dept of Aboriginal Affairs and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service
results.brief_description: Presents the cultural heritage of the first Australians through their own eyes. In an unbiased, unpatronising light it paints a realistic picture of a society whose tarnished image was created by those who supposedly made this country - the European settlers.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Richard Guthrie, Commonwealth Dept of Aboriginal Affairs and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service

results.title: A Changing culture
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Rainbow serpent”.
David Gulpilil has become a success in the white man’s world, through his acting ability and leadership of a dance troupe. Yet he prefers to live in a traditional manner with his people in Arnhem Land, making brief forays into western society in order to publicise their plight and demonstrate the richness of their culture. Charmaine Green is a linguist student at the Australian National University. When she visits her family in Mullewa, W.A. and observes the hopeless life they lead on the fringes of western society, she feels that she cannot return there permanently, although she is determined not to deny her Aboriginality in spite of her light skin.

group_works.title: Baboon social organization
group_works.creator_credit: C. Cameron Macauley and University of California, Los Angeles

results.title: Baboon social organization
results.creator_credit: C. Cameron Macauley and University of California, Los Angeles
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Baboon Social Life”.
Analyses the nature of the interdependence within a baboon troop and its close relation to baboon ecology. Discusses the role of central males, peripheral males, mothers with infants and juveniles. Suitable for secondary years 7-12.

results.title: Man: a course of study
results.brief_description: The course of study is designed for upper primary or lower secondary level but can be introduced effectively at any level. It deals with the basic questions: What is human about human beings? How did they get that way? How can they be made more so?

group_works.title: The Baboon troop
group_works.creator_credit: Quentin Brown and Educational Development Centre

results.title: The Baboon troop
results.creator_credit: Quentin Brown and Educational Development Centre
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Man: a course of study”.
Explores the social structure of members of a baboon troop. Shows the role of the male as the protector and central figure, the females’ bonds of affection for their offspring, and the establishment of the dominance hierarchy among juveniles.

results.title: Problems of World Order
results.brief_description: Each program looks at a problem or development which has implications for the whole world and which can only be solved through international cooperation. The divide between the rich and the poor nations of the world is highlighted.

results.title: Communication satellites
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Problems of World Order”.
Explores the world implications of sophisticated ommunication facilities, particularly with respect to technologically advanced and underdeveloped countries. Focuses on control problems of potential power of the Intersat and the Comsat. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Cultural heritage
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Problems of World Order”.
Tourism is now a giant worldwide industry providing an important source of revenue. This film shows how much of the heritage that we flock to see is being destroyed by tourism, modern technology and pollution. Discusses who should bear the cost and responsibility of this, using examples.
